task.title: Rendering output to PDF, EPUB, XHTML and oXygen's WebHelp
task.shortdesc: OXygen Author comes with the open source DITA Open Toolkit (DITA-OT). The DITA-OT (with the DITAforPublishers plug in) can render to common formats out of the box. At the time of writing, the PDF output is underwhelming. EPUB files are suitable for ereaders, and web-based output are suitable for browsers.

section.title: How to render different output formats
section.p: To generate the output, make sure you have displayed the top elvle map in the Author view. If you are viewing a topic rather than a map, you'll just render the topic with a choice of only PDF or XHTML (plus other projects that you've made yourself).

As well as writing in mark up (where the effects of the mark up might not be very apparent), you will also have little direct control of the appearance of the output. This includes important aspects line page breaks and the appearance of tables.It can be difficult to adjust to this, particulary when you are used to having easy control of document presentation with a word processor, and especially when the output is less satisfactory than you can acheive with one.Nevertheless, after time, it does become much simpler to just open a map and start work without being bothered by page layout, margins, and font size....advantages cond porf and transIn DITA, there is still some presentational structure to consider. Italics and bold are there, and images need to be given a (e.g width) size for PDF output (or they can spill over the page). It's still much, much less than you will find with a word processor.

section.title: PDF output
section.p: PDF output is quite poor, and is somewhat controversial. Lookng at the rendering for the first time, it doesn't seem so bad. Problems start if you want to improve it. Nevertheless, It's easy to emphasise how you or your writers will spend less time worrying about structure and more time worrying about appearance. In fact, DITA users are very interested in the appearance of their documents.You can have some direct control of the appearance of XHTML output (and by extention EPUB and oXygen's WebHelp by configuring the appearance with cascading style sheets (CSS). CSS provides a template-like way of altering the appearance. It's fairly easy to learn the basics (the web is not short of CSS tutorials) and it's well integrated woth DITA and oXygen.PDF output is much, much harder to customise. You can add some images to flag up parts of text in conditional processing, but that's about it for the DITA-OT unless you are or can call upon the skills of a developer.
Tables are particularly poor.
Changing font size, putting text in the header, and putting a logo on the front page are all very difficult, and will need involvement.
Also, currently, no index is generated.

It seems likely that the DITA-OT's PDF rendering will improve in the future and, if you will stick with DITA over a long time period, you'll be better served. On the other hand, companies offering propriatory PDF rendering produce output that is somewhat similar.
To be honest, if you need PDFoutput and you doesn't have a team of developers working for you, I'd probably not use DITA at all.

section.title: EPUB output and ereaders
section.p: You can picture EPUB files as little bundles of html code that can be read like a book.
You can read them with Adobe's Digital Editions, Firefox's EPUBreader add-on, tablets computers and ereaders.

Currently, ereaders are pretty primitive. At the time of writting, a new generation with a built-in lights has been introduced. They are really quite nice.The display refresh is still a bit slow, but they're light, portable and can be read mostly anywhere. They might be a good choice for staff working outdoors. You'll need one with EPUB support if you want to use oXygen's ebook output out-of-the-box.

When generating EPUB files, avoid using the collection-type=sequence attribute, as that will create highly annoying Previous topic and Next topic links, which are horrible in linarly-presented material like an ebook. You'll lose the nice numbering of any nested topics, unfortunately.

section.title: XHTML output
section.p: The DITA-OT generates ordinary XHTML hypertext. DITA is a reasonably straightforward technique to produce vanilla hypertext.
It is suitable for passing onto professional web developers for further processing and professional styling.

section.title: oXygen's WebHelp output
section.p: WebHelpAn additonal rendering provided by oXygen is its own "WebHelp" rendering.

This gives a contents list, a word search (which also picks up keywords you add in topic metadata) and, if you add index entries to the metadata, an index. These three cover most kinds of search very well. (Only some kind of faceted browsing is missing.)

It's also improved a lot of the last couple of years, with the addition of an index (improved over v14.0 to 14.1). The appearance of the WebHelp has changed over the years, showing it's under active development.

"WebHelp" suggests shows Syncro Soft are competing against Flare, RoboHelp and the likes, and it brings DITA back to computer application help. However, what is actually provided is a very useful, low cost way of building quite sophisticated web-sites out of the box.

I'd consider investigating this if your content will be based online only. Okay, they do put a "WebHelp output generated by oXygen" message on every page, but you could always edit the html to get rid of it. I'd just leave it.
The main problem with WebHelp is that is clearly comes from the computer help tradition. This means that it will have the unfortunate flavour of other WebHelp.

WebHelp is the kind of computer help that you find when you press F1 on otherwise access webhelp on a computer application. It usually has a disagreeably, choppy feel. Help that connects to a well-written, up-to-date web-site is usually much better.

Even WebHelp displayed using the Suite Soft HTML5 plug-in (link) still looks like DITA content. There are lots of small, disconnected topics, and the results feel much like other minimalist, ultra-topicised content.

It can actually be quite satisfying to generate WebHelp with complex structure for the first time by nesting a complex arramgement of topics. Few readers really want to read information like that though, and you might just be building an unusable toy if you do.
OXygen's WebHelp is probably the easiest and simplest way to build a maintainable process and policy web-site. Be aware of WebHelp's origin, and you should be okay.
